aws::graph::propositions: # Aviation Accident Information for Cessna 172K in Concordia, Kansas
The accident occurred in Concordia, Kansas.
The accident occurred on December 30, 2013, at 11:40 Local time.
The aircraft involved was a Cessna 172K.
The defining event was loss of control on ground.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Personal.
The accident number was CEN14CA096.
The aircraft registration was N1176M.
The Cessna 172K sustained substantial damage.
The accident resulted in 2 minor injuries.
The accident resulted in 2 people with no injuries.
The pilot reported the airplane floated during the landing approach.
The pilot had to push forward on the control yoke to finish the descent.
Pushing forward on the control yoke used about 200 feet of runway.
The landing was normal according to the pilot.
The braking effectiveness on the grass runway was insufficient to slow the airplane as expected.
The pilot elected to turn off of the runway into an adjacent farm field.
An 18 to 20 inch ridge was hidden in the tall grass along the runway.
The airplane struck the ridge.
The ridge severed the nose landing gear.
The airplane nosed over after striking the ridge.
The pilot reported no pre-impact mechanical difficulties with the aircraft.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of the accident.
The probable cause was the pilot's failure to maintain a proper glidepath during approach.
The improper glidepath resulted in the airplane landing long.
The pilot's decision to turn off the runway during the landing roll was a contributing factor.
The turn off the runway resulted in a collision with an earth berm.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Concordia, Kansas

## Date & Time: 
December 30, 2013, 11:40 Local

## Aircraft:
Cessna 172K

## Defining Event:
Loss of control on ground

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Personal

## Accident Number:
CEN14CA096

## Registration:
N1176M

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
2 Minor, 2 None

## Analysis

The pilot reported that while approaching to land the airplane floated and he had to push forward on the control yoke to finish the descent. He stated that this used about 200 feet of runway. He said that the landing was normal, but after touchdown the braking effectiveness on the grass runway was such that the airplane was not slowing as expected. The pilot elected to turn off of the runway into a farm field adjacent the runway. He said that hidden in the tall grass along the runway was a 18 to 20 inch ridge. The airplane struck the ridge severing the nose landing gear and nosing over. The pilot reported no pre-impact mechanical difficulties.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be: The pilot's failure to maintain a proper glidepath during approach which resulted in the airplane landing long, and his decision to turn off of the runway during the landing roll which resulted in a collision with an earth berm.

---
